thread.title: Business upbeat as Paddington reclaims spotlight
thread.title_full: Business upbeat as Paddington reclaims spotlight

title: Business upbeat as Paddington reclaims spotlight
text:
Food for thought at the opportunities on offer at 1 Newcombe Street in Paddington.
Paddington and other satellite suburbs are undergoing a resurgence as life is breathed into older buildings through conversions and an updated retail offering.
Having been hit by new developments such as Westfield Bondi Junction, the streets of Paddington through to Double Bay and leafy Woollahra now are back in business, boosted by pub tsar Justin Hemmes' new projects.
A shift by pub operators from the city to the suburbs because of the morning lockout laws has also created demand for food and late night shopping to cater for the increase in visitors.
Developers are keen to gain a foothold in the areas with the sought-after addresses.
Advertisement In its heyday, Oxford Street in Paddington was 100 per cent occupied. It boasted several upmarket retailers and was the place to promenade.
However, the opening of Westfield Bondi Junction in 2003 hit the area as some big names moved to the mall.
Now, it has returned to favour as retailers report stronger trading conditions.
The upturn has not been lost on developers and investors.
In the past few months, several high-profile pubs have changed hands as traditional operators move in to offer a range of services, including high-profile chefs.
Mitchell Waugh's newly formed Public House Management Group (PHMG) bought the first pub sold by the Ryan family since 1992, the Woollahra Hotel, which was home to Damien Pignolet's Bistro Moncur.
The Royal Hotel in Paddington was recently sold to the Public House Group for $15 million and the Light Brigade Hotel was bought by the Bayfield family for $9 million.
In the past year, more than than $200 million worth of pub assets have changed hands.
Ray White Hotel's Andrew Jolliffe is also selling the Four In Hand. And the Grand National was sold for more than $7 million.
Hemmes has entered with his Paddington Arms redevelopment and a new hotel in Coogee.
Supermarket chains Coles, Woolworths, Aldi and IGA also want to expand into the area and are competing for small-format convenience-based offerings.
As the major supermarkets' traditional footprint of 4000 square metres in the inner city becomes scarce, more smaller, convenience-based supermarkets will pop up in mixed use developments.
Research shows that productivity rates for niche smaller supermarkets are 32 per cent higher than regional and subregional shopping centres, and 37 per cent higher than neighbourhood centres.
New suburban high-rise developments also have limited parking so residents without cars tend to do daily, smaller shops and want a supermarket nearby that offers a range of items.
Stephen Bowrey​ and Scott Harris from Property Partnership Australia will soon be marketing a food and beverage or supermarket opportunity in Paddington called the Gordon, through an expressions of interest campaign.'
The Gordon is the Uniting Church's development at 1 Newcombe Street, comprising 19 apartments. It is near the Hemmes project and has direct exposure to the Paddington markets and Oxford Street.
Mr Bowrey said the 650-square-metre ground floor would suit a small-format supermarket or provedore that catered for the local community.
"It's the largest single retail footprint in the Paddington area to hit the market," Mr Harris said.
"We have already received some off-market interest from very renowned operators. It will be a highly sought-after location," Mr Bowrey said.
PPA is also marketing The Foveaux, a 53-apartment complex with two retail spaces on the former Legion Cabs depot site.
Craig Hibbard​ of Property Partnership said the Foveaux retail was also designed to accommodate a small-format supermarket or provedore.
